**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3**.proposition: This Court has **subject matter jurisdiction** under **G.L. c. 185C, § 3** (granting the Housing Court jurisdiction over all actions involving the health, safety, or welfare of occupants of residential housing, including actions arising under G.L. c. 186).

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of any residential premises” and any such interference entitles the tenant to **actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater**, together with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714,.support_reasoning: Blackett v. Olanoff concerns loud noise from a lounge causing constructive eviction and breach of quiet enjoyment; it does not involve failure to provide heat or utilities. The opinion does, however, *cite* earlier Massachusetts cases (e.g., Charles E. Burt, Westland Housing, Shindler) as examples where lack of heat, light, power, etc., breached quiet enjoyment absent intent. Thus, Blackett is indirect support at most; the direct authority for the proposition lies in the cited cases, not in Blackett itself.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714,.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942) (intrusions of smoke and soot... ). Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933) (failure to install necessary heating system, as agreed).

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91, 102\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91, 102\.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) to impose liability without requiring malicious or specifically intentional conduct, holding that at least reckless conduct suffices. In doing so, it emphasizes that landlord liability for interfering with quiet enjoyment is broader than deliberate wrongdoing and is grounded in failure to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions, including essential services. While this case involves flooding rather than heat/utilities specifically, its reasoning squarely supports the principle that serious failures in essential habitability services can breach quiet enjoyment absent deliberate intent.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91, 102\.relevant_excerpt: “Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… we hold that a tenant… [n]or must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.” (385 Mass. at 101–04).

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)**.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but in the context of criminal activity and lack of security in common areas, not inadequate heat or utilities. It remands for fact-finding on whether the landlord’s omissions regarding drug activity in common areas caused serious interference, and expressly notes there is no authority requiring particular security measures; it does not articulate any rule about heat or essential utilities, nor does it speak to liability absent deliberate wrongdoing in that context. Thus it does not support the specific proposition regarding heat or utilities.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that loss of heat and hot water is a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and that the landlord is liable for rent abatement without regard to fault. However, the case does not analyze or ground its holding in the covenant of quiet enjoyment; it is framed entirely as a warranty-of-habitability/rent-abatement decision. Thus it supports strict, no-fault liability for failure to provide heat and hot water, but under the warranty of habitability, not under the covenant of quiet enjoyment as the proposition states.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847, 8.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address heat or essential utilities at all, nor does it say that their inadequacy constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment absent deliberate wrongdoing. Instead, the case holds that at least negligent conduct (some degree of fault) is required for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that strict liability under another statute (here, the lead paint statute) is not enough. It therefore undermines, rather than supports, the notion that a mere failure to provide essential utilities, without fault, would automatically breach quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 847, 8.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence… we observed that the ‘Legislature may have contemplated a balance between tenant protection and the legitimate interests of landlords, and therefore may have intended that some degree of fault or foreseeability should be a prerequisite to liability under § 14.’”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855, 8.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855, 8.support_reasoning: The excerpted portion of Haddad v. Gonzalez focuses on c. 93A liability for emotional distress and on damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability; it does not analyze or decide a claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it articulate a rule that lack of heat or essential utilities, even without deliberate wrongdoing, is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although the facts include severe lack of heat and other code violations, the opinion as provided does not ground a clear holding on the covenant-of-quiet-enjoyment issue, so it cannot reliably be cited as consistent authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855, 8.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; ... The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects by August 22, 1983. He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system by September 15, 1983, and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.

*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151, 158\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151, 158\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses quiet enjoyment only in the context of plaintiff Allisan’s claim and holds that G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires a “serious” or “substantial” interference, finding no such interference on these facts. It does not address failures to provide heat or essential utilities at all, nor does it state that such failures, absent deliberate wrongdoing, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The case is primarily about G.L. c. 93A and deceptive lease clauses, not conditions like inadequate heat or utilities.
*Leardi v. Brown*, **394 Mass. 151, 158\.relevant_excerpt: “Allisan claims that the judge erroneously concluded that G. L. c. 186, § 14, requires ‘substantial’ interference with her quiet enjoyment of the premises, and thus that he erroneously denied her claim under that statute. We disagree. ‘The phrase “quiet enjoyment” is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy ...’ (emphasis added). Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982). See Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (injury must be ‘substantial’ to afford ground for relief).”

*Hilder v. St. Peter*, **144 Vt. 150 (19.raw_text: *Hilder v. St. Peter*, **144 Vt. 150 (1984)** (persuasive authority on habitability and quiet enjoyment).
*Hilder v. St. Peter*, **144 Vt. 150 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Hilder v. St. Peter*, **144 Vt. 150 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a Vermont Supreme Court decision adopting and elaborating an implied warranty of habitability, not a Massachusetts case interpreting the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment. It cites Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway for the contract-based habitability theory, but Hilder itself neither applies Massachusetts law nor discusses quiet enjoyment or the standard for breach (including whether deliberate wrongdoing is required). Accordingly, it does not itself stand as authority for how Massachusetts courts treat failures to provide heat or utilities under the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Hilder v. St. Peter*, **144 Vt. 150 (19.relevant_excerpt: The modern view favors a new approach which recognizes • that a lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition. Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 198, 293 N.E.2d 831, 842 (1973).

*Youghal, LLC v. Entwistle*, **Mass. App.raw_text: *Youghal, LLC v. Entwistle*, **Mass. App. Ct. No. 18-P-143, 2019 WL 1239874 (Mar. 19, 2019)** (unreported) (failure to maintain heating constitutes interference).
*Youghal, LLC v. Entwistle*, **Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that **failure to provide adequate heat or essential utilities** constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even absent deliberate wrongdoing.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hemingway is a separate opinion (Quirico, J., concurring/dissenting) focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of sanitary code violations on rent obligations. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, §14, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address lack of heat or utilities as a quiet‑enjoyment breach. Using this citation to show Massachusetts has held that failure to provide heat or essential utilities breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even without deliberate wrongdoing, misstates what this opinion decides.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, **363.relevant_excerpt: “The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. That holding is sufficient to dispose of the only issues raised in these cases, and to that extent I concur with the opinion.”

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A**.proposition: Pursuant to these authorities and **G.L. c. 239, § 8A**, a landlord’s failure to maintain essential services, including adequate heat, may give rise to both damages and rent abatement.
